title: 5G Communications: Which countries are using 5G technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: Service Providers are competing all over the globe to launch 5G services, soon. Verizon is the world's first service provider to launch a non-standard version of 5G in four different cities in US. They launched their first 5G service called 5G Home, a residential broadband service to their customers in the following cities. The initial speeds offered by Verizon is 300 Mbps. Verizon has announced the launch of 5G services in 4 cities, so far. Indianapolis, IndianaLos Angeles, CaliforniaSacramento, CaliforniaHouston, TexasAT&T is planning to bring standard mobile 5G and mobile 5G devices to 12 cities in 2018, and another 5 cities by early 2019. You can find a detailed 5G market update, including details on the cities where 5G will be launched by AT&T at AT&T 5G Evolution market. AT&T has achieved peak theoretical wireless speeds of 400 megabits per second for capable devices. AT&T is offering the commercial 5G solution to select “businesses and consumers” in 12 markets, beginning Dec. 21. They are using a Netgear based 5G Mobile hotspot, as part of the initial launch. Las VegasLos AngelesNashvilleOrlandoSan DiegoSan FranciscoSan JoseSan AntonioNew OrleansHoustonJacksonvilleLouisvilleDallasAtlantaWacoCharlotteRaleighOklahoma CityEE, one of the largest service providers in UK has announced that 5G services will be turned-on in 6 cities by mid-2019. Those cities are: LondonCardiffEdinburghBelfastBirmingham andManchesterSouth Korea Telecom has become the first nation in Asia to launch commercial 5G networks in Dec 2018 in Seoul and 6 other major cities. SK Telecom also started deploying 5G infrastructure in K-City, country's first city for self-driving cars, during the beginning of 2018. Deutsche Telecom (DT) launches 5G in Poland in Dec 2018 with Huawei Equipment. Their services will be available for select customers and partners. Source: First 5G Cities

China is using 5G but still has a long way to develop core technology independently. The high-tech field is China’s biggest weakness in its industrial structure so that facilitate the “Made in China 2025” plan. Over the past years, China’s reliance on U.S. telecome technology is not overhyped and make it the first target of Trump’s trade war. check ZTE’s Collapse Reveals China’s Over-Reliance on U.S. Technologies However, China has surpassed the U.S. $24 billion since 2015 and has built 350,000 new cell sites to support 5G communications, while the United States has built less than 30,000. U.S. spending on wireless infrastructure is reduced by $8 billion to $10 billion annually since 2015. The Deloitte also notes that compared to the U.S., the equipment required to install 5G in China is about 35% cheaper.  Source: Deloitte China’s 5G Arrangement China is firmly pushing ahead with its plans for commercial 5G services in 2020. Both China Telecom and China Unicom have clearly defined their plans to build a 5G Standalone network. China Mobile not only launched the “5G SA Takeoff Initiative” plan with major equipment manufacturers, but also released the “5G Device Guideline” with detailed specification requirements and procurement schedules, thus playing a leading role. It is worth noting that the Trump administration’s ban on ZTE may bring additional impetus to the positive development of China’s 5G. The U.S. government’s short but effective ban on ZTE has indeed brought panic to the Chinese market. Chinese officials are now increasingly aware of their over-dependence on the U.S. technologies and economy. Also Read: After ZTE Supply Ban, China’s Chip-making Will Step Up ZTE is also accelerating the promotion of 5G in the second half of the year as the U.S. lifts the ban. Recently, ZTE successfully completed the 3GPP R15 NSA mode 3.5GHz indoor cell site and 5G core network test. All projects were tested smoothly, fully reflecting the business capability and maturity of ZTE’s 5G system. In the coming 5G era, ZTE is indispensable to the entire industry. U.S. 5G Status Industry giants in the U.S. such as Intel and Qualcomm are working to develop top 5G technologies. It helps that this country won the 4G competition earlier this decade. U.S. wireless providers such as Verizon and AT&T, the parent company of CNN, have said they will launch 5G technology in specific markets by the end of 2018. The Trump administration has positioned 5G as a national security issue. Earlier this year, President Trump prevented Broadcom from acquiring Qualcomm for $117 billion, as U.S. officials feared that it would give China an edge over 5G technology. There is no doubt that 5G is an important factor affecting the social and economic development of China and the United States in the next few years. In the process of race, various means and tactics will be employed. The Chinese industry needs to maintain its strength and self-confidence and take every step in a down-to-earth manner.

The NEW 5G is purposefully misnamed to confuse you and will begin at frequencies much higher than that. The FCC's 5G FAST Plan “The FCC has made auctioning high-band spectrum a priority. The FCC concluded its first 5G spectrum auction this year in the 28 GHz band, and its auction of 24 GHz spectrum is taking place right now. Later this year, the FCC will auction the upper 37 GHz, 39 GHz, and 47 GHz bands. With these auctions, the FCC will release almost 5 gigahertz of 5G spectrum into the market—more than all other flexible use bands combined.” Basically the US, the UK and Canada allows Big Telecom to irradiate their populations 100 to 10,000 time more than any other country on the planet! I think I need to learn to speak German and move to Belgium.

5g is the next generation of wireless networks. Its not just faster-lower latency and more flexibility mean it could start an era of augmented self-driving vehicles and other applications whose potential has not yet been fully realized. While the pace of today’s enterprise innovation is gradually and constantly moving upwards, network providers are racing to deploy the next transformative technology: 5G. The United States and China are tied for the first place in 5G readiness, according to a report released by the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, which represents the US wireless communications industry. 5G is the platform for tomorrow’s economy and it is going to transform everything from education to AI to medicine and that becomes the reason behind everyone being so competitive. South Korea has become the first nation to officially roll out commercial 5G systems after successful 5G tests involving varied autonomous vehicles, virtual reality games. However, the current position of South Korea doesn’t ascertain the end of the global network supremacy war. This is just the sign of what seems to be tears-long competition for businesses and wireless carriers all over the world. As one of the world’s largest and advanced nations, the US wireless technology industry supports almost five million employees and contributes roughly $475 billion every year to the American economy. 5G could help bring up those numbers to sky level in a flash speed. Experts believe 5G has the potential to create up to three million new jobs- in addition to adding $500 billion to US economic growth. With proper and favorable network operator infrastructure policies, this next generation technology has the potential to give out every 100 Americans a new, 5G-enabled jobs. However, all these still needs time to get US into the global leader board in this category. While the US receives a lot of attention for its mobile technologies, Asia isn’t much far behind. With the growing technology market, it is quickly leading the way where 5G is concerned. In fact, four of the world’s five most 5G ready nations are Asian countries- China, South Korea, India and Japan. The ever increasing technological development and the government policies in China has led the nation to become a major influencer in the 5G spectrum. With a dozen tests already done, the carriers have promised to create a fully operational commercial networks for the general masses by 2020. In lieu of winning the 5G race, China has also outspent the US by almost $24 billion in order to construct more than 350,000 new 5G compatible cell towers all over the country. To join this very said race, Europe too isn’t far behind. In Europe, governments are joining forces with network operators to establish 5G testing regimes that not only upgrade the existing connectivity but also do so while trying to protect systems in a way that doesn’t require the inclusion of foreign vendors which comes as a response to the US pressure to ban technology providers in the grounds of national security. Wireless carriers in this region believe these bans are not only highly unsubstantiated, but could negatively impact the supply of 5G enabled equipment, increases costs for the industry and consumers, also delay the rollout of future 5G services by several years along with the handicap of the existing networks- which in turn threatens to jeopardize the billions of investments Europe expects to make by 2025. As 5G grows more permeating, the demand for mobile data will only keep increasing at a constant rate. If the promise to provide 100 times faster speeds for 100 times mire devices at a more receptive rate, they will need the spectrum and infrastructure to accommodate all the next-gen needs of say, higher spectrum. At the end of the day, 5G can only be as successful as government allows. Policies that allows and prioritize innovation, technology as well as enterprise growth must not only be promoted but also be put up as the highest leader on the score board that is set out to win the 5G race. By putting legislation in place that rationalizes infrastructure planning mobile network siting, and operator licensing processes, a nation can dramatically hasten the deployment of it 5G enabled technology initiatives.

5G is defined as the 5th generation of a cellular network that has advanced broadband capabilities. 5G infrastructure is a basic step required to formulate a set of comprehensive #software and hardware resources of the #network . The Global 5G Technology Market is accounted for $33.67 billion in 2017 and is expected to reach $3482.89 billion by 2026 growing at a CAGR of 67.44% during the forecast period. Currently, 5G #technology for cellular systems is in the early development stages. There are several companies and universities that have set up 5G research units that are generally focused on developing the technologies for 5G. The standards bodies, in addition, 3GPP, in particular, do have knowledge of of the development but aren’t proactively outlining 5G systems yet. The Countries which are trying to use 5G Technology are as follows: • North Americao USo Canadao Mexico• Europeo Germanyo UKo Italyo Franceo Spaino Rest of Europe• Asia Pacifico Japano Chinao Indiao Australiao New Zealando South Koreao Rest of Asia Pacific• South Americao Argentinao Brazilo Chileo Rest of South America• Middle East & Africao Saudi Arabiao UAEo Qataro South Africao Rest of Middle East & Africa  5G technology is projected to have a massive impact on next-gen infrastructures. It is likely to play an important role in powering future cities, industries, transport, homes, etc. The high-performance network capacity of 5G technology is prompting service providers and telecom operators to invest in the technology. 5G connectivity is going to provide better speeds and coverage than other connectivity. The technology operates with a 5 GHz signal and offers a speed up to 1GB per second.

5G or 5th generation is the latest generation of cellular mobile communications. It succeeds the 4G, 3G and 2G systems. 5G performance targets high data rate, reduced latency, energy saving, cost reduction, higher system capacity, and massive device connectivity. 5G will be able to fix bandwidth issues. Currently, there are so many different devices connected to 4G networks, that they don’t have the infrastructure to cope effectively. 5G will be able to handle current devices and emerging technologies as well. But it must be remembered that these scenarios are all still theoretical and imaginary and it will take a lot of investment by governments and mobile network operators to make these work and to become reality. The security aspect of 5G also still needs to be figured out. With a greater number of users and improved services, 5G opens the door to a new level of threat. Governments and mobile operators must ensure they have the advanced level of security in place before 5G is rolled out. The top countries, which have already launched their 5G Networks are South Korea, China, Japan and The United States. UK also launched 5G recently and many other countries are progressing fast to launch their 5g network.

Future of 5G Wireless Ecosystem For Extreme Bandwidth Augmented Reality Applications And Connectivity Management of M2M (Strategies & Forecasts 2016-30) While LTE and LTE-Advanced deployments are still underway, mobile operators and vendors have already embarked on R&D initiatives to develop so-called “5G” technology, with a vision of commercialization by 2020. 5G is essentially a revolutionary paradigm shift in wireless networking to support the throughput, latency and scalability requirements of future use cases such as extreme bandwidth augmented reality applications and connectivity management for Billions of M2M (Machine to Machine) devices. Get Sample Report With TOC @ The 5G Wireless Ecosystem: 2016 Although 5G is yet to be standardized, vendors are aggressively investing in 5G development efforts with a principal focus on new air interface transmission schemes, higher frequency bands and advanced antenna technologies such as Massive MIMO and beamforming. With large scale commercial deployments expected to begin in 2020, we estimate that 5G networks will generate nearly $250 Billion in annual service revenue by 2025.

The US media website NowThis recently created an informative segment on 5G networks, their potential uses and achievable browsing and download speeds and its launch in future. Below is the video-  0:00-0:30 As described, there are several countries like US, Canada, etc. that are trying to bring 5G to reality. In India, Reliance Jio has already tested the potential uses of 5G and are readying the infrastructure needed to provide 5G coverage to its nearly 300 million subscribers. The Jio 5G ecosystem consists of chipsets and peripherals that are compatible with 5G. This shall be available by early to mid 2020. The 5G based products and devices are also in pipeline and shall be available to users for affordable prices starting from 2021. Reliance Jio, partnering with Ericsson, showcased a live demo of what exactly 5G technology can bring to its users at the 2018 Indian Mobile Congress. A prototype driverless car at Reliance Corporate Park (RCP) in Mumbai was controlled using 5G technology from about 1,388-km away at Aerocity grounds. This primarily demonstrates the efficiency and lower levels of latency which has the potential to connect entities in real time, irrespective of the distance. There were also surveillance drones on display and an aerial disaster management vehicle SKYSHIP, with facial recognition features for rescue activities. Reliance Jio is one of the leading telecom companies in the world and in the coming years shall offer not just 5G technology to all its users but also new augmented and virtual reality experiences on devices.

As others have answered, 5G is not available yet. In order for transactions to be completed in the speed set out in the technical specifications (currently Ericsson claims to be able to round trip a transaction in 9 milliseconds yet the industry target is 1 millisecond!), the territory needs to be blanketed with cellular sites. To get to the next site, and back again within that 9 milliseconds means that the signal cannot have far to travel. Achieving the necessary densification will cost billions and it is not at all clear where the return on investment will be generated. We have not yet tackled the real problem - it is not just getting a signal there and back within an incredibly short period of time, it is that something is supposed to be done with that signal. A useful analogy: you ask a question and get the answer in 9 milliseconds. Obviously, asking a question and getting an empty answer packet back in 9 milliseconds will not be helpful. So, 5G compliant applications must be able to receive the ‘question’ develop and send the ‘answer’ and still stay within the 9 millisecond limit. So, while many countries and companies are talking about rolling out 5G radio technology, customers are not going to experience anything like 1 millisecond response, or 9 millisecond response for many years to come. Faster than current 4G/LTE yes, but not close to the spec anticipated by the standards groups for 5G.

The world is racing to implement 5G infrastructure, in expectation of future demands. Here is the Pie chart which shows the comparison of the geographical distribution of 5G (in percentage).  First adopters embracing 5G will gain a competitive edge over the others, and it looks like China is currently leading the way. According to the various source, Asian countries like China, South Korea, Japan, and the US (outside Asia) are investing and building 5G infrastructure. Since 2015, China has spent the most money on 5G and the amount is about US$24 billion which is more than any other countries. These numbers are momentous, as the potential economic impact of 5G far outweighs the improvements recorded when the industry transitioned from 3G to 4G.  Hope it helps you! OKportal Technology

No country has 5G yet. It may start to change in a year, perhaps even in 2018. Lots of tests are taking place in individual cities across the world. Nokia and Ericsson are the top European providers of the 5G infrastructure – Nokia in particular has a lot of success in the oil-rich Arab world and even in China – and ironically, Chinese competitor Huawei is more successful elsewhere. In the U.S., Samsung – a non-player in the rest of the world – develops some 5G etc. Europe is the slowest region to introduce 5G. But there are attempts and planned tests in coming months in Italy, Czechia, and elsewhere. On the other hand, Korea, Japan, China, U.S. are doing fine. You may follow Google News searches about Nokia 5G nokia 5g - Google Search and similar ones for the other companies. Lots of things are happening but the technology isn’t ready for general usage yet.

The list grows by each week as operators in several different countries turn up new 5G networks. For anyone looking to track this information, it can be difficult to follow. There is a resource created by Ookla, known for developing the Speedtest app, that provides a really nice interactive map of the countries that have deployed 5G.  For example, if you zoom into a region like Europe, it provides more detail on the areas with active 5G networks.  For even more detal, I chose to zoom in on Spain to see what's new here.  The map is updated once a week[1]. It's super friendly and gives a nice overview of which countries have 5G deployed. Footnotes[1] Tracking 5G Network Rollouts Around the World

Like previous generations, 5G is a set of evolved network technologies. But 5G aims to provide unlimited access to information and the ability to share data anywhere, anytime by anyone and anything for the benefit of people, businesses and society. The exact performance levels and requirements that systems and equipment will need to meet to label themselves 5G are yet to be defined. The standardization activities are expected to start around 2016, leading to commercial availability of equipment and devices sometime around 2020. But this does not mean that vendors and manufacturers are waiting around. Like most other ICT players, Ericsson is working to ensure that 5G will enable the thousands of new use cases, to evolve existing technologies, research complementary ones, and work toward a smooth transition to 5G that provides benefit without impact on carbon footprint. Now the %g technology is in developing stage to know more just consider the expert article on 5g technology .

Currently, two major international organizations are writing the standards defining 5G: the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP). Together, they are working on a timeline set by the ITU to put standards in place by 2020, when most mobile network providers expect 5G services will be available to the public. You can read this article (https://technode.com/2018/03/30/5g/) that looks into the US vs. China race for 5G, and discusses why it matters who develops 5G first and how close China is to developing a global standard. This article (https://www.wsj.com/articles/washington-woes-aside-huawei-is-determined-to-lead-the-way-on-5g-1522402201) also gives great insight into the current 5G development efforts of Chinese smartphone maker Huawei.

Mobile 5G as of now appears to be on its way to becoming the next big thing in the global digital connected ecosystem. The ever-increasing demand for an enhanced mobile broadband experience together with smartphone adoption are the new trends in consumer engagement. It is expected to increase data density resulting in these collectively being the critical drivers for 5G. According to estimates, the global mobile data traffic will grow by more than 200 times from 2010 to 2020 and by nearly 20,000 times from 2010 to 2030. As of now, no country has launched 5G technology. In fact, right now its parameters , such as speed, frequency and communication-technology has not be finalised. After these parameters are defined , it would then move to the next station, which is planning how to design communication channel. As per a study, it would still take around atleast 4-5 years that first 5G communication takes place in a lab ( and not by the operator commercially) The highest technology in use is LTE-Advanced and VoLTE technology. Various operators in the US and South Korea have been able to achieve theoritical speed of 300 Mbps. As of now, study regarding 5G is being done in the US, Japan, EU and South Korea. Its being anticipated that with 5G, operators aim to cross 1GBps mark and first such commercially viable network might be created by 2025.

All eyes are on China now as the country is in a leading role in the race of 5G development. The top-down national agenda that came with a series of key initiatives has provided instrumental support to create a complete ecosystem in the market – from technology R&D, equipment, network, terminals, platform, to application development. Intense engagements from the entire value chain are developing new use cases and service platforms that may serve as international test beds for 5G innovation. China’s preparation for 5G is well underway, as it enters the third phase of 5G testing while the government has officially reserved considerable contiguous spectrum for 5G purpose. With the global unified standard set to finalize this year, China has brought forward its timetable of the commercial launch to 2019, potentially becoming one of the first 5G-ready markets in the world. Economies such as India, Korea, and China will contribute significantly due to a number of ongoing developments & initiatives. The government of South Korea has invested huge sums in the R&D of 5G technology. Regional Segmentation http://snip.ly/ku03q  It has also promised a trial of this latest technology next year. The U. S. market will register the highest growth rate over the next few years. This can be attributed to the growing number of subscriptions in the region.

5G makes its move in the UK!  5G networks such as EE can deliver impressive speeds – but only outdoors at present. Photograph: The Guardian The future of mobile phones is finally here. You can go out and buy a 5G phone, and if you happen to be in one of the six cities across the UK (London, Cardiff, Belfast, Edinburgh, Birmingham, and Manchester) in which EE’s 5G network is up and running, you can get the blistering mobile broadband speeds we’ve been promised will revolutionize our mobile lives, again. But should you? I’ve spent the past two weeks equipped with the OnePlus 7 Pro 5G on first-out-of-the-gate EE’s 5G network. I streamed 2K HDR movies, downloaded whole albums in seconds and generally used it on my extremely fast 350Mbps home wifi – data caps be damned. So what is 5G like, and is it worth buying into? The answer to both those questions is … complicated. See Also: How govt. can encourage innovation.  Speeds in St. Pauls were some of the highest in London. Photograph: EE Is 5G faster than 4G? Absolutely. Day to day in the most congested parts of London, it was at least double the speed of EE’s 4G, sometimes up to 10 times faster. That meant speeds varied wildly as I trundled through patches of 5G on the train. At Elephant and Castle in the morning rush hour, I got a full 5G signal, but only speeds of about 3Mbps – still double the 1.5Mbps 4G could produce at the same time. A few hundred meters down the tracks stuck outside Blackfriars, speeds in eoverMbps were routine, with 4G capping out at less than 30Mbps. A similar experience was had outside Victoria and several other central London stations. Read More for Further Details:

At present: nowhere. It is all a big marketing hype - a race to close contracts based on the 5G speed promises. The truth is: 5G first wave addresses industrial applications and fixed line broadband supply for undersupplied regions. For the consumer there is still LTE. And that situation will not change for the next 5 years or so. LTE will start using the new 5G frequencies, and thus be sold as 5G. The full strength of 5G can only be seen when the radio nodes are (software) upgraded to support New Radio, AND we have the new core network in place.

No country as of yet (June 2016). As many of you are aware, we wont see proper 5G until 2018.  This roadmap from a recent Samsung presentation[1] provides a view of when 5G Phase 1 and 5G Phase 2 will be officially available.  Some operators like AT&T are more aggressive and they are already trialling what they call 5G[2], but this is just a trial with limited set of features. Real 5G will not be available untill standards are defined in Mid 2018. Footnotes[1] The 3G4G Blog: 5G & 802.11ax[2] AT&T's 5G Trials

5G Communications is a new trend that is going to disrupt the economy. Currently, 5G technologies are used by, The United States, South Korea, Japan, Turkey, China. Moving forward, it will enter a lot more countries. People are now very accepting and open to change and will accept this technology and use it for their benefit.

Right now many countries are with LTE. Then you have LTE-A , then LTE-A pro. After all this you have 5G. But right now it's on testing stage. Last year, Qualcomm tested 5G speed in it's lab using X50 LTE modem that achieved speed in gigabits per second.

No country has a 5G network as the standards have still not yet been ratified. You may be surprised to hear that many countries still don’t have 4G networks. Where I live, even 2G coverage is very patchy and 3G is non-existent.

It will take time. 5G Development work is still going on. It will be in two phase. First phase is completely focused on research work both in 28GHz and 60 GHz band, where many companies and universities ( primarily in Europe, Japan, Korea and USA) are participate. Second phase will be focused on defining standards and roll-out of technology. By 2020, 5G prototype should be available.https://srventechconsultancy.com/2017/12/21/5g-buzz-and-where-are-we/
